text: Hey, what's up creators? My name is Luke
and welcome back to the first hour of
Unreal Engine course. In this video,
we're going to be showing you how we can
import custom graphics into Unreal
Engine that we can use on our headsup
display. Specifically for our headsup
display, we're going to be showing you
how we can take our coin counter and
just import a coin image and a
background image for this as well, just
so our heads up display looks a little
bit nicer. Not only that, you're going
to be able to use this process as the
foundation for building all of your user
interfaces moving forward. We're going
to jump into Unreal Engine in just a
moment. But what I do want you to do is
make sure that you have watched the very
first video in this module where we show
you how you can download our assets that
we're providing for the user interface
as part of this course. Let's hop into
Unreal. So, inside of Unreal Engine,
what we're going to do is we're going to
go to our content drawer and we're going
to go into our first hour of Unreal
Engine folder. Again, inside of here,
we're going to create a brand new
folder. And I'm just going to give this
the name UI assets. And I'm going to
open this up. Then, to import my images,
all I'm going to do is go to import.
I'm going to navigate to my desktop and
I'm going to find my UI assets folder.
And then what I'm going to do is I'm
just going to import my coin and my
center frame. These are the two that
you're going to need for now. And we're
going to go ahead and press open. And
what that's going to do is simply import
the images that we provided for this
user interface into Unreal Engine. Now,
you will have probably noticed with
these images, they are PGs with
transparent background, but this is all
we need for now. Bringing them into our
widget blueprints again, really
straightforward. What we're going to do
is go back a folder and we're going to
open up our headsup display. Go to our
design view and we're going to start
working with images.
So, if we go to image in our pallet, we
can drag and drop this in. and we're
just going to do the background to start
with.
I'm also going to anchor this to the
bottom center.
And then once we've done that, we can
start using our images. So to bring our
image into the appearance for this with
our image selected we're going to go to
brush image and then we can either find
it in here and we can do that by either
typing typing in the name or by going to
our UI assets and then just finding our
counter frame in our content drawer
and then with this press the use
selected asset from content browser
button to bring that image image in. And
just like that, we now have the counter
in the bottom center of our screen. And
I could, of course, put the text onto
this. But notice the text is displaying
underneath this image. And that's where
we now need to interact with something
called the Zorder. The Zorder is
essentially just going to be the order
in which our components are being
rendered. So if we have a higher number,
it's going to be rendered on top. So, if
I click on my text, because I want this
to be the very top layer in my details,
I'm going to set my Z order to one. And
now, if I click on this and drag it
over, you can see it's now displaying on
top of my counter. Perfect.
Let's add another image component in
here. And this time, we're going to use
brush image, and we're going to search
for coin.
So that way we can find our coin image.
And then we're just going to scale this
and bring it in. Again, just making sure
we're anchoring these all to the bottom
center. So with that done, we've now got
each of the components in here in terms
of we've got our background, we've got
our coin image, and we've also got the
text and everything displaying
correctly. What I want to do now is just
take a quick 30 seconds or so to look at
the reference image that we've got to
see what the sizes of all of this should
be and the colors of the text. So that
way we can just get this looking good.
The reference image is of course
provided as part of the UI assets
folder. And I'm going to open this up.
And the main thing to note is the coin
is on the right hand side. It's got
equal edges here padding. And then the
text is almost as big as the coin, but
it's white. Let's go back into Unreal
Engine and make this happen. So, I'm
going to put my text on the left hand
side. And I'm going to put my coin on
the right hand side.
Going to make my text white by simply
clicking on it. Going to color and
opacity and setting this to white. Going
to make this a little bit smaller. Just
going to set this to font size 50.
And then I am just going to drag this
into place here. And then my coin. Just
going to scale this up
until it looks good. So it's something
like this.
And then I'm just adjusting the scale of
my background piece until it looks good.
And I'm also just nudging it over by
just clicking on it and using the arrow
keys.
But just like that, we have now got a
coin counter
and it looks pretty good and it's got
custom graphics. If I was to compile and
press play, you can see now in the
bottom of our screen, we have got our
coin counter and it's looking good. And
again, I can run up to each of these
coins,
collect them, and I can see that number
is going to go up. Okay, so that's it
for this video. By now, you should have
a good understanding of the process of
creating a widget blueprint, how to
actually create text and bind things to
it. But more importantly, as part of
this video, we showed you how to import
custom graphics so you can style all of
this up and make it look good. Move on
to the next module where we're going to
be going over the game over screen. But
for now, I hope you have enjoyed it.
Stay awesome. Keep creating.
